statement.text: Completion duplex ultrasound is a non-invasive intraoperative imaging technique used to assess vascular reconstructions, particularly vein bypasses. This modality provides real-time B-mode imaging of the graft and anastomoses plus Doppler velocity measurements to detect stenoses. Peak systolic velocity (PSV) >180 cm/s or velocity ratio >2.0 indicates a hemodynamically significant stenosis requiring revision. Completion duplex avoids radiation and contrast while providing functional flow data.
statement.formal: Completion Duplex: Sterile ultrasound probe (7.5-10 MHz) → B-mode imaging (graft, anastomoses) → Doppler velocity measurements → Criteria: PSV >180 cm/s or ratio >2.0 = stenosis | No radiation, no contrast | Best for: Vein grafts, visible/palpable reconstructions

explanation.intuition: Completion duplex is like doing an ultrasound to look at your bypass graft the same way you'd look at a baby in the womb - you're using sound waves to see the structure and measure how fast blood is flowing. If blood is moving too fast at one point, it means there's a narrowing there, just like water speeds up when you put your thumb over the end of a garden hose.
explanation.key_insight: The combination of anatomic (B-mode) and functional (Doppler velocity) data makes duplex uniquely valuable. Unlike angiography, which only shows anatomy, duplex tells you if a stenosis is actually affecting flow. A PSV >180 cm/s or velocity ratio >2.0 (compared to adjacent normal segment) is the threshold for hemodynamic significance that warrants revision.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Cover linear ultrasound probe (7.5-10 MHz) with sterile sheath; (2) Apply sterile saline or gel for acoustic coupling; (3) Scan entire graft from inflow to outflow; (4) Obtain B-mode images of proximal anastomosis, graft body, distal anastomosis; (5) Measure peak systolic velocity (PSV) at each anastomosis and any suspicious areas; (6) Calculate velocity ratio (PSV at stenosis / PSV in adjacent normal segment); (7) Assess graft diameter, wall abnormalities, intimal flaps; (8) For vein grafts, evaluate for retained valve leaflets, twist, or size mismatch. Criteria for revision: PSV >180-200 cm/s at focal stenosis, velocity ratio >2.0-2.5, visible intimal flap, B-mode diameter stenosis >50%.
common_misconceptions: Duplex is only for surveillance, not completion studies - intraoperative duplex is highly accurate
You need a dedicated ultrasound technician - surgeons can learn to perform and interpret
Angiography is always better - duplex provides velocity data that angiography cannot
Duplex misses problems that angiography catches - detection rates are comparable

definitions_glossary.peak_systolic_velocity: Maximum velocity of blood flow during systole, measured in cm/s
definitions_glossary.velocity_ratio: PSV at stenosis divided by PSV in adjacent normal segment
definitions_glossary.b_mode: Brightness mode ultrasound showing two-dimensional grayscale image
definitions_glossary.doppler_shift: Frequency change of reflected sound waves used to calculate velocity
definitions_glossary.color_flow: Ultrasound mode showing direction and relative velocity of blood flow

indications: When contrast is contraindicated (allergy, renal failure)
Surgeon preference for functional velocity data
contraindications: Deep reconstructions not accessible with ultrasound
Aortic surgery (requires angiography for adequate visualization)
Critically unstable patient requiring rapid closure
No available ultrasound equipment or expertise

scanning_protocol: Entire graft body (look for stenosis, twist, kink)

b_mode_findings.normal: Smooth wall, adequate diameter, no filling defects
b_mode_findings.abnormal: Wall thickening, intimal flap, diameter stenosis, thrombus

complications.prevention: Use hemodynamic criteria, not just B-mode appearance

definition.@value: Intraoperative ultrasound imaging combining B-mode and Doppler to assess vascular reconstructions for technical errors

sources.citation: Bandyk DF, et al. Intraoperative duplex scanning: a new technique for vascular surgery. J Vasc Surg.
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Intraoperative Assessment.

learning_objectives: Describe the technique of completion duplex ultrasound
Interpret velocity criteria for hemodynamically significant stenosis
Compare duplex to angiography for intraoperative assessment
Perform intraoperative duplex with proper technique
clinical_pearls: PSV >180 cm/s or ratio >2.0 = significant stenosis - this is your threshold
Duplex is ideal for vein grafts - you can see the whole graft and measure velocities
The velocity ratio is more reliable than absolute PSV for detecting stenosis
Completion duplex establishes a baseline for postoperative surveillance
If duplex and clinical exam disagree, get an angiogram to settle it

medicalCode.description: Duplex scan of arterial inflow and venous outflow for preoperative assessment
